So much by way of prelude: Wyclil now attacks his main point os the relative honour due to kings and priests, and at the outset has to sace a formidable diffi- culty. Alter the disappearance of Count Baldwin of F landers his brother Henry reigned as Emperor at Constantinople in his stead, well and wisely enough. But in the Church os St. Sophia he had the temerity to place the Patriarch os Constantinople on his lest hand and apparently on a lower seat (iuxta scabellum pedum suorum in sinistra parte). This outrage drew down on him a vehement reproof from Pope Innocent ΙΙΙ (the Pope to whom King John had to surrender his crown)‚ and this reprool in which the sacerdotal pretensions are very strongly stated, was enshrined in the Decretals. ‘Now in considering this decree,’ says Wyclil, ‘we must be on our guard against its ignorant interpreters ;’ in other words he proceeds to meet it bya series of dis- tinctions. Thus it is granted that the priestly order excels the kingly, but in a special, not in a secular or civil sense. The priestly dignity can be honoured by God solelyper accadens, quite apart from the infinitely higher claim to honour which virtue may conser on it. And is the Patriarch is to be honoured with outward observance in proportion to his priestly dignity, then no seat will be good enough for so great a man!
